hud_ammo_show.desc: Switches showing of current ammo value.

hud_ammo_style.desc: Switches graphical style of current ammo value.

hud_armor_align_x.desc: Sets horizontal align of armor level.

hud_armor_align_y.desc: Sets vertical align of armor level.

hud_armor_digits.desc: Sets number of digits for armor level.

hud_armor_frame.desc: Sets frame visibility and style for armor level.

hud_armor_frame_color.desc: Defines the color of the background of the armor HUD element. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_armor_order.desc: This defines the order of drawing the HUD elements. That means you can change will be drawn on top of other elements. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_armor_place.desc: Sets relative positioning for armor level.

hud_armor_pos_x.desc: Sets horizontal position of armor level.

hud_armor_pos_y.desc: Sets vertical position of armor level.

hud_armor_style.desc: Switches graphical style of armor level.

hud_armordamage_align.remarks: See HUD manual for more info.

values.description:
horizontal: left, center, right, before, after
vertical: top, center, bottom, console, before, after

hud_armordamage_align_x.desc: Sets armordamage HUD element horizontal alignment.
hud_armordamage_align_x.remarks: See HUD manual for more info.

hud_armordamage_align_y.desc: Sets armordamage HUD element vertical alignment.
hud_armordamage_align_y.remarks: See HUD manual for more info.

values.description: top, center, bottom, console, before, after

hud_armordamage_digits.desc: Sets highest possible number of digits displayed in HUD element armordamage.

hud_armordamage_duration.desc: Sets how long armordamage should be visible after last damage to armor has been done.

hud_armordamage_frame.desc: Sets frame visibility and style for this HUD element.

values.description: Use floating point values from range 0..1 to get alpha transparent background or 2 to get bevel frame.

hud_armordamage_frame_color.desc: Defines the color of the background of the armordamage HUD element. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_armordamage_order.desc: This defines the order of drawing the HUD elements. That means you can change will be drawn on top of other elements. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_armordamage_place.desc: Sets placement for this HUD element. You can align some elements relative to other elements.
hud_armordamage_place.remarks: First you have to decide, if the element that you are locating now (element B) is to be positioned inside another element (element A) or outside it. See HUD manual for more info.

values.description: to place this element inside element B set this variable to "@B", to place it outside B element set this variable to "B"

hud_armordamage_pos_x.desc: Sets horizontal position of this HUD element.

hud_armordamage_pos_y.desc: Sets vertical position of this HUD element.

hud_armordamage_scale.desc: Sets overall size of this HUD element.

hud_armordamage_show.desc: Toggles visibility of this HUD element.

hud_bar_armor_direction.desc: Direction of colored part inside HUD element that designates amount of armor.

hud_bar_health_direction.desc: Direction of colored part inside HUD element that designates amount of health.

hud_clock_big.desc: Switches unsing larger version of clock.

hud_clock_format.desc: Controls in what format the clock is displayed.

hud_clock_frame.desc: Sets frame visibility and style for clock.

hud_clock_frame_color.desc: Defines the color of the background of the clock HUD element. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_clock_order.desc: This defines the order of drawing the HUD elements. That means you can change will be drawn on top of other elements. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_clock_scale.desc: Size of the clock HUD element.

hud_democlock_align_x.desc: Vertical alignment of the democlock HUD element. See the HUD manual for more info.

hud_democlock_align_y.desc: Vertical alignment of the democlock HUD element. See the HUD manual for more info.

hud_democlock_big.desc: Enables larger version of the democlock.

hud_democlock_frame.desc: Opacity of the background of the democlock HUD element.

hud_democlock_frame_color.desc: Defines the color of the background of the democlock HUD element. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_democlock_order.desc: This defines the order of drawing the HUD elements. That means you can change will be drawn on top of other elements. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_democlock_place.desc: Placement of the democlock HUD element. HUD elements can be place into various screen areas or other elements. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_democlock_pos_x.desc: Horizontal relative position of the democlock HUD element.

hud_democlock_pos_y.desc: Vertical relative position of the democlock HUD element.

hud_democlock_scale.desc: Size of the democlock HUD element.

hud_democlock_show.desc: Visibility of the democlock HUD element.

hud_digits_trim.desc: Changes how large numbers are treated in Head Up Display.
hud_digits_trim.remarks: Applies to all HUD elements with 'digits' property.

values.description: 10030 will be displayed as "999" with hud_*_digits 3
10030 will be displayed as "030" with hud_*_digits 3
10030 will be displayed as "100" with hud_*_digits 3

hud_editor_allowalign.desc: Should aligning be allowed when using the HUD editor?
hud_editor_allowalign.remarks: This can also be toggled when in the HUD editor by using the F3 button.

values.description: Dissallow aligning in the HUD editor
values.name: false

values.description: Allow aligning in the HUD editor (alt + mouse 1)
values.name: true

hud_editor_allowmove.desc: Allow moving HUD elements when in HUD editor mode.
hud_editor_allowmove.remarks: This can also be toggled when in the HUD editor by using the F1 button.

values.description: Dissalow moving objects in the HUD editor
values.name: false

values.description: Allow moving objects in the HUD editor.
values.name: true

hud_editor_allowplace.desc: Allow placing HUD elements in HUD editor mode.
hud_editor_allowplace.remarks: This can also be toggled when in the HUD editor by using the F4 button.

values.description: Dissallow placing HUD elements in the HUD editor
values.name: false

values.description: Allow placing HUD elements in the HUD editor (ctrl + mouse 1)
values.name: true

hud_editor_allowresize.desc: Allow resizing HUD elements in HUD editor mode.
hud_editor_allowresize.remarks: This can also be toggled when in the HUD editor by using the F2 button.

values.description: Dissalow resizing HUD elements in the HUD editor

hud_face_align_x.desc: Sets horizontal align of player face.

hud_face_align_y.desc: Sets vertical align of player face.

hud_face_frame.desc: Sets frame visibility and style for player face.

hud_face_frame_color.desc: Defines the color of the background of the face HUD element. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_face_order.desc: This defines the order of drawing the HUD elements. That means you can change will be drawn on top of other elements. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_face_place.desc: Sets relative positioning for player face.

hud_face_pos_x.desc: Sets horizontal position of player face.

hud_face_pos_y.desc: Sets vertical position of player face.

hud_fps_align_x.desc: Sets horizontal align of fps counter.

hud_fps_align_y.desc: Sets vertical align of fps counter.

hud_fps_decimals.desc: How many decimal number should the FPS HUD element contain.

hud_fps_drop.desc:
Sets the value which will trigger displaying the fps (requires hud_fps_style 2 or 3). For example, with value hud_fps_drop 70, the fps will only be displayed if it drops to 70 or below. For fps values greater than 70, the fps will not be displayed.
Can also be set to a negative value, interpretted as relative to cl_maxfps

hud_fps_frame.desc: Sets frame visibility and style for fps counter.

hud_fps_frame_color.desc: Defines the color of the background of the fps HUD element. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_fps_order.desc: This defines the order of drawing the HUD elements. That means you can change will be drawn on top of other elements. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_fps_place.desc: Sets relative positioning for fps counter.

hud_fps_pos_x.desc: Sets horizontal position of fps counter.

hud_fps_pos_y.desc: Sets vertical position of fps counter.

hud_fps_style.desc: Alters how and when the fps is drawn. Please see hud_fps_drop for styles 2 and 3.

values.description: white text, fps will show only if the client's fps is less than or equal to hud_fps_drop value

hud_fps_title.desc: Switches displaying the text "fps" of fps counter.

hud_frags_align_x.desc: Sets horizontal align of frags bar.

hud_frags_align_y.desc: Sets vertical align of frags bar.

hud_frags_bignum.desc: Changes the scale of the fragcount number.

values.description: If this is 0 the fragcount will use the normal charset. If it's above 0 it will scale a big number character instead.

hud_frags_cell_height.desc: Sets cell height of frags bar.

hud_frags_cell_width.desc: Sets cell width of frags bar.

hud_frags_colors_alpha.desc: Sets the opacity of the players colors for the frags hud element.

hud_frags_cols.desc: Sets number of columns of frags bar.

hud_frags_extra_spec_info.desc: Enables to see when people have rocket launchers, lightning guns, powerups and how much health and armor they have using icons next to the frags. Works while watching MVD demo.

values.description: Show RL, LG, powerups armor and health.
values.name: ALL

values.description: Show powerups, armor and health. (No RLs/LGs)
values.name: POWERUPARMORHEALTH

values.description: Show RL, LG, powerups and health. (No armor)
values.name: RLLGPOWERUPHEALTH

values.description: Show RL, LG, powerups and armor. (No health)
values.name: RLLGPOWERUPARMOR

values.description: Show RL, LG, armor and health. (No powerups)
values.name: RLLGARMORHEALTH

hud_frags_fliptext.desc: Toggles alignment of players nick and team name in frags HUD element.
hud_frags_fliptext.remarks: Use 'frags shownames 1' and/or 'frags showteams 1' to show names and team names of players.

values.description: Rows aligned to the left side, names and team tags are on the right side of frag counts.
values.name: false

values.description: Rows aligned to the right side, names and team tags are on the left side of frag counts.
values.name: true

hud_frags_frame_color.desc: Defines the color of the background of the frags HUD element. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_frags_maxname.desc: The max number of characters to use for displaying the names in the frags element.

hud_frags_order.desc: This defines the order of drawing the HUD elements. That means you can change will be drawn on top of other elements. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_frags_padtext.desc: Toggles text padding in 'frags' HUD element.

hud_frags_rows.desc: Sets number of rows in frags bar.

hud_frags_shownames.desc: Draws players names next to frag counts in 'frags' HUD element.

hud_frags_showself_always.desc: Forces the client to show the part of frags table where you are.

values.description: Display the part of table where you are.
values.name: true

hud_frags_showteams.desc: Draws players' team tags next to frag counts in 'frags' HUD element.

values.description: Golden brackets around your own frags field.
Arrow pointing to your own frags field.
Red rectangle around your own frags fiels.
Sets background color for your own field to 'teamcolor'.

Background color for whole table 50% transparent red, your own field not transparent.
Red background color only for your own field including name and team tag.

hud_frags_teamsort.desc: Switches sorting by teams in frags bar.

values.description: Countdown from match time to zero
values.name: true

hud_gameclock_frame.desc: Opacity of the background of the gameclock HUD element.

hud_gameclock_frame_color.desc: Defines the color of the background of the gameclock HUD element. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_gameclock_offset.desc: Allows using gameclock in custom mods that don't support standard KT-like clock synchronization.
hud_gameclock_offset.remarks: Some Capture The Flag or Team Fortress mods can take a use of this.

hud_gameclock_order.desc: This defines the order of drawing the HUD elements. That means you can change will be drawn on top of other elements. See HUD manual for more info.

hud_gameclock_style.desc: Sets the style of the gameclock hud element.

values.description: Only highlight the name of the player (show_names needs to be on)
Draw a variably sized circle outline around the tracked player.
Draw a fixed sized circle outline around the tracked player.
Draw a variably sized circle around the tracked player.
Draw a variably sized circle around the tracked player.
Draw a line from the bottom center of the radar to the tracked player.
Draw a line from the center of the radar to the tracked player.
Draw a line from the top center of the radar to the tracked player.
Draw a line from each corner of the radar to the tracked player.

hud_radar_highlight_color.desc: Sets the RGBA color of the highlight of the tracked player for the radar HUD element.

hud_radar_itemfilter.desc: Decides what items should be shown on the radar. Such as ammo, health packs, backpacks and powerups.
hud_radar_itemfilter.remarks: Any character/whitespace can be used as a delimiter. Make sure you enter the value between quotes if you use whitespaces.

values.description: Valid values: backpack, health, armor, rockets, nails, cells, shells, quad, pent, ring, suit, mega

hud_radar_onlytp.desc: Decides whetever the radar hud item should be shown only when in teamplay mode, or demo playback.
hud_radar_onlytp.remarks: The radar will NOT be visible when playing as a normal player no matter what you set this to, this only applies to spectators/during demo playback.

values.description: Only show when teamplay is on.
Only show when in demo playback.
Only show when teamplay is on and in demo playback.
0 is fully transparent and 1 is opague.

hud_radar_otherfilter.remarks: Any character/whitespace can be used as a delimiter. Make sure you enter the value between quotes if you use whitespaces.

values.description: Valid values: projectiles, nails, rockets, shaft, gibs, explosions

hud_radar_show_height.desc: Should the players become bigger as they move to higher points on the map or not?

values.description: Players always stay the same size on the radar.
values.name: false

values.description: Players change size depending on their altitude on the level.
values.name: true

hud_radar_show_hold.desc: This will show the name of all the important items on the map (RL, LG, GL, SNG, Quad, Pent, Ring, Suit, Mega, Armors). A circle is drawn around the items, the team who has the highest weight inside this area is considered to be holding that particular item. See the teamholdinfo hud item.
hud_radar_show_hold.remarks: It is not recommended to have this visible at all times. Instead it's meant for a  quick glance to know which item is named what when using the Teamholdbarinfo hud item. For instance if the map has two YA's, one is named YA and the other YA2. Use this feature to see which is which.

values.description: Don't show the items and circles on the radar.
values.name: false

values.description: Show the item names and circle on the radar.
values.name: true

hud_radar_show_names.desc: Show the names of the players on the radar.

hud_radar_show_powerups.desc: Highlight players with powerups on the radar hud item with a colored circle around them, depending on what type of powerup.

hud_radar_show_stats.desc: Decides what type of stats should be shown on the radar.
hud_radar_show_stats.remarks: The team stats are calculated depending on how strong a player is. A strong player with a good weapon raises the weight for a certain area more than a weak one. The team with the highest weight for a certain area is considered to hold that area.

hud_radar_weaponfilter.desc: Decides which weapons that should be shown on the radar.
hud_radar_weaponfilter.remarks: Any character/whitespace can be used as a delimiter. Make sure you enter the value between quotes if you use whitespaces.

hud_score_bar_format_big.desc: Format string for score_bar HUD element.
hud_score_bar_format_big.remarks:
%d - score difference between you and enemy.
%D - score difference between you and enemy, red chars.
%t - team score.
%T - your (team) score, red chars.
%e - enemy (team) score.
%E - enemy (team) score, red chars.
%d - score (team) difference.
%D - score (team) difference, red chars.
%p - your (team) position on scoreboard.
%z - score difference between you and enemy, unsigned. Red chars used for negative difference.
%z - score difference between you and enemy, unsigned. Red chars used for positive difference.

hud_score_bar_format_reversed_big.desc:
Format string for score_bar HUD element, used when hud_score_bar_fixed_order has taken effect.
If not set, hud_score_bar_format_big will be used instead.

hud_score_bar_format_reversed_small.desc:
Format string for score_bar HUD element, used when hud_score_bar_fixed_order has taken effect.
If not set, hud_score_bar_format_reversed_small will be used instead.

hud_score_bar_format_small.desc: Format string for score_bar HUD element.
hud_score_bar_format_small.remarks:
%d - score difference between you and enemy.
%D - score difference between you and enemy, always signed.
%t - your (team) score.
%T - your (team) name.
%e - enemy (team) score.
%E - enemy (team) name.
%d - score difference.
%D - score difference, always signed.
%p - Your (team) position on scoreboard.

Also, you could use color codes.

hud_score_bar_frag_length.desc: Minimum number of characters to use when displaying frags.

values.description: Use big characters (num* and anum* images)

ignore_flood_duration.desc: You can change the 4 second cooldown with the 'ignore_flood_duration' variable.

image_jpeg_quality_level.desc:
You can set quality of jpeg screenshots with 'image_jpeg_quality_level x' where x is an integer from 0 to 100 inclusive.
The larger x is, the better the quality of a jpeg screenshot, but also the bigger the size.

image_png_compression_level.desc:
You can set the amount of png compression with 'image_png_compression_level x' where x is an integer from 0 to 9 inclusive.
0 gives no compression and 9 gives maximum compression (and slowest writing time).

in_builtinkeymap.desc: Allows you to use old Quake keyboard mapping.

values.description: Use your operating system keyboard layout
values.name: false

in_di_buffered.desc: Direct Input: Use Immedia data instead of buffered mode of reading.
in_di_buffered.remarks: This setting has been added only because Direct Input allows such mode of use. It is not going to decrease input lag, make the mouse responsiveness better, or anything like that. Read the official documentation on Direct Input to know the difference between buffered and immediate mode of use.

values.description: Use events buffer to process the input data
values.name: true

in_di_bufsize.desc: Size of the direct input buffer.
in_di_bufsize.remarks: On some circumstances the default size does not have to be sufficient.

in_evdevice.desc:
Specify device for evdev mouse.
Should be absolute path like /dev/input/event0.
Use in_evdevlist command to get lost of devices.
in_evdevice.remarks:
You should have read access to your device.
sudo chmod 644 /dev/input/event* should help you if you have trouble.

values.description: absolute path to mouse event device

in_grab_windowed_mouse.desc: If set, will grab mouse input when not fullscreen.

in_ignore_deadkeys.desc: Ignores operating-system interpretation of keypresses while deadkey is held down

values.description: Enabled when option keys are held down
Enabled when alt keys are held down (for standard keyboard on MacOS)

in_ignore_touch_events.desc: If set, will ignore events from touch inputs (events from a real mouse should be unaffected)

in_ignore_unfocused_keyb.desc: If set, will ignore keyboard events received immediately after regaining focus.  Should stop shortcut keys from firing in-game.

in_m_os_parameters.desc: Allows you to use your system mouse settings in the client.

values.description: Do not keep any of the system mouse settings
Keep both acceleration and speed settings

in_m_smooth.desc:
Enables advanced mouse smoothing.
You have to be using Direct Input for this to work.

in_mmt.desc:
Multithreaded mouse.
For most users in_mmt 1 + evdev gives the most smooth input.

values.description: Read mouse data in main thread
values.name: false

values.description: Use separate thread for reading mouse data
values.name: true

in_mouse.desc:
Different types of mouse input
[OBSOLETE in ezQuake 3.0]
in_mouse.remarks: Linux: You have to set in_evdevice to proper value (/dev/input/eventX). Use command in_evdevlist to get the lost of proper values. Also in_mmt makes your mouse more smooth.

values.description: Windows: standard mouse; Linux: DGA mouse
Windows: Direct Input; Linux: X Mouse
Windows: Raw Input; Linux: EVDEV mouse

in_raw.desc: Whether or not ezQuake will use raw input to sample mouse events.
in_raw.remarks: It is recommended to leave this set.

in_raw_allbuttons.desc:
Forces RAW Input handler to treat more incoming signals as mouse buttons.
Helps if you cannot get some mouse buttons working in the game.

values.description: Only standard set of events is interpreted as mouse buttons
values.name: false

values.description: More events are interpreted as mouse buttons
values.name: true

in_release_mouse_modes.desc: Controls under which mode(s) the cursor will be released back to the operating system when not fullscreen.
in_release_mouse_modes.remarks:
To specify more than one mode, add the values together.

To always release the cursor, set in_grab_windowed_mouse 0.

irc_server_address.desc: IP address of the IRC server to connect to on irc connect command.

irc_server_port.desc: Port number for IRC server connection.

irc_user_nick.desc: Your nickname used to log-in to the IRC server.

irc_user_realname.desc: Real name field used to log-in to the IRC server.

irc_user_username.desc: Username used to log-in to the IRC server.

keymap_name.desc:
This holds the name of the current keymappings; it has (currently) only informational purposes.
If no keymapping is active, it will contain the name "Default".
If a keymapping will be active and no name has been set, "Custom" will be used as name. It can easily be set with "keymap_name <layoutname>"

values.description: Will convert all non printable characters to printable characters in your log. This makes your log readable because all the weird ascii characters that usually occur because of different colored text in the client (and because of weird symbols - ocrana led's etc) are converted into printable characters.
values.name: true

lookspring.desc: This variable toggles the centering of the screen after the -klook command.

lookstrafe.desc:
This variable toggles the automatic strafing when the +klook command is used.
When set to "1" and the player used the +klook command, the keys that are bound to the +left and +right commands will now act as if they were bound to +moveleft and +moveright.
This command was put it in order to allow keyboard player to combine the +strafe and +klook commands into one.
This command also has effect on the mouse controls. When set to "1" moving the mouse left and right will make the player move left and right instead of making him turn left and right.

m_accel.desc:
Values >0 will amplify mouse movement proportional to velocity.
Small values have great effect.
A lot of good Quake Live players use around the 0.1-0.2 mark, but this depends on your mouse CPI and polling rate.

m_accel_offset.desc:
Acceleration will not be active until the mouse movement exceeds this speed (counts per millisecond).
Negative values are supported, which has the effect of causing higher rates of acceleration to happen at lower velocities.

m_accel_power.desc:
Values 1 or below are dumb.
2 is linear and the default.
Above 2 begins to amplify exponentially and you will get more acceleration at higher velocities. Great if you want low accel for slow movements, and high accel for fast movements. Good in combination with a sensitivity cap (m_accel_senscap)

m_accel_senscap.desc: Sets an upper limit on the amplified mouse movement. Great for tuning acceleration around lower velocities while still remaining in control of fast motion such as flicking.

m_filter.desc:
This variable toggles mouse input filtering.
When set to "1", the values which are received from the mouse's input will first be averaged together and then that value will be used in the game.
The reason for this command is that some mice had problems with sending sporadic coordinates which make the input from the mouse jerky, also when using a serial or PS/2 mouse, the Windows operating system will only sample mouse input every 25ms, that is 40 times a second (for USB mice the sample rate is 125 Hz, that is every 8 ms).
When set to "1" this variable will smooth out the input but it will cause latency between the movement of the mouse and the actual response in the game.
When using a PS/2 mouse it is thus first recommended to try to increase the sampling rate either by changing it via your mouse driver or by using the ps2rate program which can be downloaded at ps2rate homepage.
If you are playing the game at frame rates above 40 FPS and if you can't increase the sampling rate of your PS/2 rate or if you are playing with a serial mouse it is recommended that you enable this toggle.

values.description: If you have problems to get MWHEELUP and MWHEELDOWN working set this to 1.
values.name: true

m_forward.desc:
This variable controls how fast the player should move forward and back when the mouse is moved forward and back.
This command has no effect if the +mlook command is in effect because when the mouse is moved forward and back the player looks up and down instead of moving forward and back.
Some players might want to set this variable to "0" if they happen not to use +mlook constantly and they only want to use the mouse to turn the player.
Setting this variable to "0" will prevent the inadvertent movement of the player forward and back while trying to make precise turns with the mouse.

m_pitch.desc:
This variable sets the level of precision when the mouse is used to make the player look up and down while the +mlook command is in effect.
By default this variable is set in such a way that moving the mouse forward makes the player look up and moving the mouse backward makes the player look down.
Some people prefer to have this movement inverted just like it is inverted for airplane controls.
If you wish to use this inverted mouse movement then you should set this variable to a negative value (for example "-0.022"). It is a matter of preference which movement method is used by players.
Also lowering the value for this variable will increase the level of precision when the mouse is used to make the player look up and down.
This variable can be used separately from the sensitivity variable to provide greater control over the mouse sensitivity for movement along the pitch. It is advisable to keep the value for this variable constant at 0.022 or -0.022 and instead use the sensitivity variable to change the overall sensitivity of the mouse.
Also, some script writers lower the value for this variable along with a lowered value for the fov variable in order to provide more precision when the fov variable is used to zoom.

m_rate.desc:
This variable should be set to your mouse rate (in Hz).
Note: need -m_smooth and -dinput to commandline.

m_side.desc: When the +strafe command is active or when "lookspring" is set to "1" this variable is used to control the sensitivity when the mouse is moved left and right to make the player move left and right.

m_yaw.desc:
This variable controls how fast the player turns left and right when the mouse is moved left and right.
It is recommended that this variable be left alone and instead the "sensitivity" variable is used to change the level of precision.
If you set this variable to a negative value you will reverse the mouse movement.
Some script writers use this variable to increase the level of precision when the "fov" variable is used to zoom the screen.

mapname.desc: Contains the name of the current map.

match_auto_logconsole.desc: When set to 1 or 2, a temp console log will automatically be created when a match starts (usually when the countdown starts).

values.description: Auto record console but requires manuall saving. See 'match_save'.
Automatically saves the console log after the match is completed.

match_auto_logupload.desc: Automatically upload match console log to remote server specified in match_auto_logurl.

match_auto_minlength.desc: When using 'match_auto_record 2', temp demo's auto recorded won't be saved automatically if they are shorter than the number of seconds match_auto_minlength' is set to.
match_auto_minlength.remarks: If a temp demo is too short to autosave, you can still save it manually with "match_save".

match_auto_record.desc: When set to 1 or 2, a temp demo will automatically be recorded when a match starts (usually when the countdown starts).

values.description: Demo will be recorded but requires manual saving with match_save
Automatically saves the demo after the match is completed.

match_auto_spectating.desc: When set to 1, auto recording will also occur when in spectator mode.

values.description: Don't auto record demos in spectator mode.
values.name: false

values.description: Auto record demos even in spectator mode.
values.name: true

match_auto_sshot.desc:
Set to 1 to automatically take a screenshot of the final scoreboard when a match ends.
If your console is down or you are in the menus, then the client will remove the console/menu for a split second so it can take a screenshot of the scoreboard without any interference.

values.description: Take auto screenshot on match end.
values.name: true

match_auto_unminimize.desc: Bring client from minimized state on countdown start.

match_challenge.desc:
When enabled, sends announcements to duel ladder server about match start and match end.
Can be activated by special startup *.qw file or by opening special qw: URL.

match_challenge_url.desc: Web address where POST requests announcing challenge match start and end will be sent.

For example, there is match_format_duel, match_format_2on2, etc, etc. All these variables can contain macro's that are expanded according to the macro list given below.  You can also use the "match_format_macrolist" command inside the client to display a list of the macros and their meaning.
match_format_2on2.remarks: See 'match_format_macrolist' command and Match tools manual for more info.

values.description: This pattern will be used in following situation: (gamedir = "qw", 2 teams with at least 1 team having 2 people)

match_name_nick.desc: %n uses this if its not "", otherwise it uses your in game name.

match_name_spec.desc: This is placed after your nick when using %n and are in spec mode. Eg. if you use "match_name_nick foo" and leave match_name_spec default, then %n will be "foo(SPEC)" in spec mode and "foo" when not in spec mode.

menu_botmatch_mod_old.desc: If set, starting a botmatch through multiplayer menu will disable features that cause problems for older mods that spawn bots as non-clients.

menu_marked_fade.desc: Speed of menu entry highlight flashing. Zero disables the flashing effect.

mvd_autotrack.desc:
Turns auto-tracking function ON / OFF.
This feature can be used while watching MultiView Demo. The client will choose and switch to the best player point of view using appropriate algorithm.
mvd_autotrack.remarks: You can change the switching algorithm properties using mvd_autotrack_1on1, mvd_autotrack_2on2, etc. variables. The setting no. 4. cannot be customized and is independent on other autotrack client settings, except of mvd_autotrack_lockteam.

values.description: Autodetect current gametype and use the appropriate xonx settings
Force the use of mvd_autotrack_custom* settings
Enables the use of mvd_multitrack_1 - 4 allowing to set seperate algorthms for every window with cl_muiltiview 2-4

Simple algorithm which prefers pent+rl over quad+rl, quad+rl over pent, quad over noquad, weapon over no weapon player
Cannot be customized

Shows information of the player you are currently tracking.

Information includes:
 - Taken/dropped items and powerups.
 - Last 3 runs (including the current one)
Run is from powerup-took/spawn to powerup-end/death.

mvd_status_x.desc: Adjusts the horizontal placement of mvd_status table.

mvd_status_y.desc: Adjusts the vertical placement of mvd_status table.

mvd_write_xml.desc: Enables dumping of XML stats from a MVD.

net_tcp_timeout.desc: Timeout (in ms) when making TCP connections (such as connecting to QTV)

noaim.desc: This variable toggles whether a server-sided aiming-help should be used when shooting rockets (not possible when the server variable "sv_aim" is set to "0").

values.description: Enable server-side aiming help for rockets (if allowed by the server).
values.name: false

values.description: Disable server-side aiming help for rockets.
values.name: true

values.description: Enable skins but do not download new skins.

password.desc: Password players have to use to connect to local server.

pm_airstep.desc:
Airstep player-move-extension.
Changes the physics of the game and allows to do jumps on stairs.

pm_bunnyspeedcap.desc:
This is experimental code intended to restore class balance in TF.
If you set this cvar to something like 1.5 or 2, a solider will not be able to bunnyhop as fast as a scout does :)
Note that this cvar is optional and disabled by default, so it will in NO WAY affect gameplay unless you set it explicitly to anything but 0.

pm_ktjump.desc:
If enabled (the standard), when the player jumps, velocity will always be at least 270 (standard jump).
Without this set, jumping when moving down a slope would result in lower velocity.

pm_pground.desc:
Enables 'persistent onground flag' physics tweak.
Its only use is that it makes pm_airstep work better.
pm_pground.remarks: This extension makes use of Z_EXT_PF_ONGROUND to ensure correct movement prediction by clients. Prediction errors shouldn't be very noticeable anyway even with old clients.

pm_slidefix.desc: When set to 1, Upon decsension from a sloped surface, the player doesn't "drop" (which is a bug in QW), but smoothly slides, as it was in NQ.

qconsole_log_say.desc: Log chat messages into the main server console log.

qport.desc: Local port the client uses to connect to servers.

qtv_adjustbuffer.desc:
Enables balancing of the buffer length of the QTV stream.
When turned on, the size of the stream buffer (the delay from the actual action) will be auto-adjusted (by changing the playback speed when necessary) so that it stays on the same level most of the time.
qtv_adjustbuffer.remarks:
When turned on, the speed of the playback may change sometimes - that's how the buffer length is balanced. But usually you want to have this turned on when you are watching a shoutcast-commentated game because you want to stay synchronized with the commentary.
See qtv_buffer hud element for monitoring.

values.description: Do not adjust buffer size, always play at 100% speed
Auto-adjust buffer size, to stay within % of total buffer length (see /qtv_buffertime, /qtv_adjustlowstart, /qtv_adjusthighstart)
Auto-adjust buffer size, to stay close to total buffer length (see /qtv_buffertime)

qtv_adjusthighstart.desc:
The level on which QTV buffer auto-adjusting will start.
E.g. when set to 1.5, (and qtv_adjustbuffer is 1), QTV buffer auto-adjusting will start when buffer length reached 150% of it's normal length (determined by qtv_buffertime setting)

values.description: Only values higher than 1.0 make sense

qtv_adjustlowstart.desc:
The bottom level on which QTV buffer auto-adjusting will start.
E.g. when set to 0.5, (and qtv_adjustbuffer is 1), QTV buffer auto-adjusting will start when buffer length reached 50% of it's normal length (determined by qtv_buffertime setting)

values.description: Only values lower than 1.0 make sense

qtv_adjustmaxspeed.desc:
The fastest possible playback speed when QTV buffer becomes excessive and auto-adjusting starts.
The higher the speed is, the faster the QTV buffer length will go down to normal levels.

qtv_adjustminspeed.desc:
The slowest possible playback speed when QTV buffer adjusting takes action.
The slower the speed is, the faster the QTV buffer will fill up.
qtv_adjustminspeed.remarks: Not allowing to slow down enough, buffer level might still drop down to zero if there were longer network lag. This causes pausing during playback. Allowing to slow down too much is noticeable.

values.description: 0.5 means 50% of the normal playback speed

qtv_allow_pause.desc: Allows QTV streams to be affected by cl_demospeed.

qtv_api_url.desc: URL used by /qtv command to resolve servers to QTV addresses and vice versa.

qtv_buffertime.desc: Defines how much the client buffers from the QTV stream.
qtv_buffertime.remarks: This determines the "delay" you will get from what is actually happening. For example if you want to synchronize shoutcast commentary with the QTV stream, this is the variable you need to change.

values.description: in seconds, values below 0.5 are treated as 0.5

qtv_chatprefix.desc: String that will be added at the beginning of all messages send to a QTV chat.

qtv_event_changename.desc: Text pattern used when an user changes his name on a QTV stream.

qtv_event_join.desc: Text pattern used when an user joins a QTV stream.

qtv_event_leave.desc: Text pattern used when an user leaves a QTV stream.

qtv_gamechatprefix.desc: String that will be added at the beginning of all messages send from QTV to the server where the broadcasted game is being played.

qtv_maxstreams.desc: Maximum number of simultaneous QTV connections.

qtv_password.desc: Password required for QTV to connect to the streamport.

qtv_pendingtimeout.desc: Number of seconds to wait before timing out a pending QTV connection.

qtv_prebuffertime.desc: Number of seconds to buffer before starting playback from QTV, or 0 to use /qtv_buffertime.

values.description: in seconds, values below 0.5 are treated as 0.5
say_team will be blocked when sending to QTV.
values.name: false

values.description: say_team allowed as normal on QTV.
values.name: true

values.description: QTV chat messages will have prefix detailing userIDs and proxy addresses
values.name: false

values.description: QTV chat messages will be in simpler form <name>: <message>
values.name: true

qtv_streamport.desc: Server variable, TCP port on which the server will listen for QTV connections.

qtv_streamtimeout.desc: Number of seconds to wait before timing out a QTV stream.

values.description: Use path relative to your quakedir

r_aliastransadj.desc: Not much is known about this variable except for that increasing the value will cause the player models to be displayed smaller.

r_aliastransbase.desc: Not much is known about this variable except for that increasing the value will cause the player models to be displayed smaller.

r_ambient.desc:
This variable controls the amount of ambient lighting on the map.
When this variable is increased the map will become brighter and all walls and objects will be rendered in a lighter color.
It was removed in QWCL and has been re-introduced in this client, however it can only be used when the server is running with cheats enabled (for example "qwsv -cheats"), because it could be used as a cheat by making it easier to see players in dark corners when no fullbright skins are used.

r_bloom.remarks: Lights will have a "diamond" effect near them.

r_bloom_alpha.desc: Transparency level of the blooming effect.

r_bloom_darken.desc: Level of "darkness" of the blooming effect.

r_bloom_diamond_size.desc: Size of the diamond particle used in the blooming effect.

r_bloom_fast_sample.desc: Faster variant of the blooming effect.

r_bloom_sample_size.desc: Size of the particle used in the blooming effect.

values.description: 0 mean no icons at all, 0.5 mean half opacity and 1 is opaque.

r_clearcolor.desc: This variable changes the color of the areas outside the map, commonly seen when free floating as a spectator.

r_damagestats.desc: Displays the amount of damage taken recently on the screen above your armour and health.

r_drawdisc.desc: Displays an indicator in top-right of screen when disk IO is in progress.

r_drawentities.desc:
This variable can be used to disable that any object entities are drawn.
This command is useful to map authors who wish to take a look at their map without drawing any objects such as lifts, buttons, platforms or items.

r_drawflat.desc: Disables textures and walls and floors them with a solid color (/r_wallcolor or /r_floorcolor) depending on the angle.
r_drawflat.remarks: Usually used for performance improvements at the expense of eyecandy. See /r_wallcolor, /r_floorcolor & /r_drawflat_mode.

values.description: Use basic textures for walls and floors.
Use colored floors and textured walls.
Use colored walls and textured floors.

r_drawflat_mode.desc: Sets the method used to adjust wall & floor textures (/r_drawflat) by the corresponding color (/r_wallcolor & /r_floorcolor)
r_drawflat_mode.remarks:
Works in GLSL modes only (see /gl_program_world).
Mode 0 will give best performance, mode 2 is the recommended setting for different colors.

values.description: Walls/floors will be solid color, as per /r_drawflat setting
Walls/floors will be textured but then scaled as per /r_wallcolor & /r_floorcolor settings
Walls/floors will be solid color (see /r_wallcolor & /r_floorcolor), but brightness will be set by the underlying texture

r_drawparticles.desc:
Toggles drawing particle effects.
Intended for helping isolate rendering performance issues.

r_drawviewmodel.desc: Controls transparency level of the currently-held weapon.
r_drawviewmodel.remarks:
Example: 0.5 = 50% transparency.
r_drawviewmodel 2 will cause weapon to be hidden when fov > 90.

r_drawvweps.desc: Whether to draw vweps (other players' weapon models).
r_drawvweps.remarks: In order for vweps to work, you must have the appropriate models (vwplayer.mdl and w_*.mdl), and the server you're playing on must have vwep support enabled.

values.description: Do not display renderer speed statistics.
values.name: false

r_dynamic.desc: Controls dynamic lighting (muzzle-flash, quad & rocket glow, etc) on world surfaces.

values.description: Display dynamic lighting (calculated on GPU - GLSL only)

r_enemyskincolor.desc: Allows you to set color for enemies you see in RGB format.

r_explosionLight.desc: Size of the light effect around explosions.

r_explosionLightColor.desc: Determines the color of the explosion light.

r_explosionType.desc: Sets the type of effect used for explosions.

r_farclip.desc: Can be used to overcome vision being limited to 4096 units in GL clients (good for xpress2 etc).

values.description: Enable fastsky, helps fps a bit on maps with large sky areas.
values.name: true

values.description: All turbulences will be displayed normally.
values.name: false

values.description: All turbulences will be replaced by single-colored surfaces.
values.name: true

r_floorcolor.desc:
Changes color of floors and ceilings when r_drawflat is set to 1.
Enter RGB value here, e.g. r_floorcolor "128 128 128" goes for gray floor.

r_fullbright.desc:
This variable toggles the use of lights at full brightness on the map.
This allows map authors to remove all of the lighting effects from the map, effectively removing all shadows.
r_fullbright.remarks: This variable can only be used when the server is running with cheats enabled (for example "mvdsv -cheats" or sv_cheats 1), because it could be used as a cheat by making it easier to see players in shadows.

values.description: Fullbrights the map (need -cheats or sv_cheats 1 enabled in server)
values.name: true

r_fullbrightSkins.desc:
Determines the fullbright percentage of skins.
Fullbright skins can always be used during demo playback.
The f_skins response will indicate the brightness level being used as a percentage.

r_fx_geometry.desc: Outlines the world based on surface normals.

r_glstats.desc: When enabled, it creates a window in the top right of the screen showing the number of particles and etc. in use.

r_graphheight.desc: This variable used to set the number of lines displayed in the "r_timegraph" command.

values.description: Orange/Yellow Plasma Rocket Mk II trail.
Similar to 3, but with a white line and less smoke.

r_instagibTrail.desc: Type of trail to use when viewing trails left in /instagib mode.

r_lavacolor.desc: Changes color of lava when r_fastturb set to 1.

values.description: Enable smoothing (watch people moving in mvd demos with cl_demospeed 0.1).
values.name: true

values.description: No fix for interpolated muzzle flashes.
values.name: false

r_lgbloodColor.desc:
Determines the color of the blood (for standard particles).
The QW-default value is 225.

r_lightdecayrate.desc:
Determines how fast lights decay (radius decreases).
Minimum value 1 (QWCL)

values.description: Blend map textures and bsp entities (ammo, health etc.)

r_maxedges.desc:
This variable sets the maximum number of plane surface edges to be rendered.
Actual default (and minimal) value is 2000.
On some new maps you may need to increase this value.
See also r_maxsurfs, r_reportedgeout, r_reportsurfout.

r_maxsurfs.desc:
This variable sets the maximum number of plane surfaces to be rendered.
Actual default (and minimal) value is 2000.
On some new maps you may need to increase this value.
See also r_maxedges, r_reportedgeout, r_reportsurfout.

r_netgraph.desc:
Netgraph is a diagnostic tool to help you tweak your rate.
If you find that you suffer from short pauses in the game and you see red spikes in your netgraph, you should try setting the rate down a bit.
The height of the pink lines towards the bottom is your latency on received packets.
Red lines are lost packets. (bad)
Yellow lines are from the rate command kicking in, it's data that wasn't sent to you because you didn't have the bandwidth for it. (OK)
Blue lines are very bad, they invalid delta's, and are related to the U_REMOVE warnings.
r_netgraph.remarks: If during your play, you frequently see a string of messages with the term "U_REMOVE" in them, and your play seems to freeze for serveral seconds, use the console command cl_nodelta 1. This is a slightly less efficient way for QuakeWorld to work, but if your ISP is overloaded or has some configuration problems, it may not pass packets to QuakeWorld properly and cause difficulty.

r_netstats.desc:
Shows information about ping, packetloss, average packet size and incoming/outgoing traffic.
Equivalent with 'net' HUD element.

r_novis.desc:
This variable toggles the use of VIS information from the map data.
When this variable is set to "1" the game will calculate it's own VIS information on the fly instead of using the information stored in the map data, this will cause a severe performance penalty in the game.
When "r_novis" is set to "1", the variable "gl_turbalpha" has a value lower than "1" and the server allows the client to display liquid transparently the player will be able to see through liquids.
This is a nice effect to see but it is not recommended to keep this variable set to "1" because of the huge performance penalty.
It is possible to enable transparent liquids and still keep this variable set to "0" (and thus not experience such a severe performance drop) by using maps that are VISed accordingly.
You can visit the official Water VIS site at "http://www.sod.net/" and download the vispatch program along with the patch data files which you would use to update the VIS data for all of your game maps.
There are also map packs available that contain VISed versions of the original ID maps.

values.description: Do not calculate VIS information for unVISed maps.
values.name: false

values.description: Calculate VIS information for unVISed maps.
values.name: true

values.description: Do not print information about the number of edges.
values.name: false

values.description: Print information about the number of edges.
values.name: true

values.description: Do not print information about the number of surfaces.
values.name: false

values.description: Print information about the number of surfaces.
values.name: true

r_particles_count.remarks: You can adjust graphics performance with this.

values.description: Do not print polygon model statistics.
values.name: false

values.description: Powerup glow is turned off on all players.
Disables the powerup glow from yourself only.

r_railTrail.remarks: See /r_instagibTrail for customising /instagib mode in KTX.

values.description: Orange/Yellow Plasma Rocket Mk II trail.
Similar to 3, but with a white line and less smoke.
Do not report when running out of edges.
values.name: false

values.description: Report when running out of edges.
values.name: true

r_reportsurfout.desc:
Toggle the display of how many surfaces where not displayed.
This shouldn't happen during normal game play, only when in noclip mode.

r_rocketLight.desc:
Enables rocket lights.
Values from 0-1 can be used to scale the light.

values.description: Enable dynamic rocket lights, maximum scale.

r_rocketLightColor.desc: Determines the color of the rocket lights.

values.description: Orange/Yellow Plasma Rocket Mk II trail.
Similar to 3, but with a white line and less smoke.
Do not display shadows for entities.
values.name: false

r_shaftalpha.desc: Adds transparency to the lightning gun beam (shaft).

r_shiftbeam.desc: Shift start of the shaft lights.
r_shiftbeam.remarks: Doesn't work with smackdown ruleset. Intended for movies.

r_skincolormode.desc: Toggles different modes of how colors from r_enemyskincolor and r_teamskincolor are applied to players.

r_skincolormodedead.desc: Sets r_skincolormode for players upon death.

values.description: Do not change r_skincolormode when player dies.

r_skycolor.desc: Changes color of sky when r_fastsky set to 1.

r_skyname.desc: If you wan't to use skybox name snow type r_skyname snow, disable skybox with r_skyname ""

r_slimecolor.desc: Changes color of slime when r_fastturb set to 1.

r_speeds.desc:
Toggles the displaying of drawing time and stats of what is currently being viewed.
Example:
32.7 ms 267/196/ 74 poly   3 surf
38.6 ms 267/196/ 74 poly  20 surf
60.4 ms 267/196/ 74 poly  18 surf
38.2 ms 267/196/ 73 poly  18 surf

r_teamskincolor.desc: Allows you to set color for teammates you see in RGB format.

r_telecolor.desc: Changes color of teleport when r_fastturb set to 1.

r_tracker_align_right.desc: Controls the alignment of the extra frag messages window.

values.description: Extra frag messages window will be shown on the left side of the screen.
values.name: false

values.description: Extra frag messages window will be shown on the right side of the screen.
values.name: true

r_tracker_color_bad.desc: Color to use when reporting a frag by opponent's team.

r_tracker_color_fragonme.desc: Color to use when reporting an opponent killed the current player.

r_tracker_color_good.desc: Color to use when reporting a kill by current player's team.

r_tracker_color_myfrag.desc: Color to use when reporting a frag by current player.

r_tracker_color_suicide.desc: Color to use when reporting a suicide.

r_tracker_color_tkbad.desc: Color to use when reporting a teamkill by current player's team.

r_tracker_color_tkgood.desc: Color to use when reporting an opponent's teamkill.

r_tracker_flags.desc: Everytime you take, capture or drop a flag, the number of times is displayed on the screen.
r_tracker_flags.remarks: See r_tracker_*, cl_parseFrags and cl_loadFragFiles variables description for further info.

r_tracker_frags.desc: Controls which frag messages will be shown in extra window, beside the standard onscreen chat (notify area).
r_tracker_frags.remarks: Values 1 and 2 requires cl_loadfragfiles and cl_parsefrags to be set to 1.

values.description: Frag messages related to yourself will be shown in extra window.
All frag messages will be shown in extra window.

r_tracker_frame_color.desc: Controls the opacity and color of the background of the extra frag messages window.
r_tracker_frame_color.remarks: See other r_tracker_* variables description for further info.

values.description: <r g b><a> = red, green, blue and alpha values 0..255.

r_tracker_images_scale.desc:
Controls the size of images when using the tracker.
Valid range 0.1-10.

r_tracker_inconsole.desc: Controls how tracker messages will appear in the console/notify area.
r_tracker_inconsole.remarks: To see full death messages in the console, use con_fragmessages 2.

values.description: Tracker messages will not be shown in the console.
Tracker messages will be shown in console and notify area (disables regular tracker messages)
Tracker messages will be shown in console and notify area (regular tracker messages enabled)
Tracker messages will be shown in console and regular tracker area but not in notify area.

r_tracker_messages.desc: Maximum number of custom frag messages to be displayed in extra frag messages window.
r_tracker_messages.remarks: See other r_tracker_*, cl_parseFrags and cl_loadFragFiles variables description for further info.

r_tracker_name_width.desc: Maximum length of player names in the tracker.

r_tracker_own_frag_prefix.desc: Text to show before frag messages relating to the current player.

r_tracker_positive_enemy_suicide.desc: If enabled frag tracker draws enemy suicides using color value of r_tracker_color_good variable.

r_tracker_proportional.desc: Enable TrueType fonts on tracker text.

r_tracker_scale.desc: Allows you to change the font size in the extra frag messages.

r_tracker_streaks.desc:
Everytime a player makes a set number of consecutive kills, it will display a message showing they are on a streak.
When the player is killed, it will display the name of the person who ended that streak.

r_tracker_string_died.desc: Text appearing in the tracker when a player dies (typically lava, slime, drowning etc)
r_tracker_string_died.remarks: Relates to PLAYER_DEATH rules in fragfile.dat.

r_tracker_string_enemy.desc: Text appearing in the tracker when a player earns a frag.
r_tracker_string_enemy.remarks: Relates to X_FRAGS_UNKNOWN rules in fragfile.dat.

r_tracker_time.desc: Number of seconds the tracker information is drawn on the screen.

r_tracker_x.desc: Adjusts the position of extra frag messages window.
r_tracker_x.remarks: See other r_tracker_* variables description for more info.

r_tracker_y.desc: Adjusts the position of extra frag messages window.
r_tracker_y.remarks: See other r_tracker_* variables description for more info.

r_turbwarp.remarks:
SW only!
This variable has the same effect as r_waterwarp in other quake clients.

r_viewmodelSize.desc:
This allows you to change the size of the viewmodel (the model of your active weapon displayed on the center of your screen) a little.
Useful if you prefer to use "r_drawviewmodel 1" and higher fov values (for demos for example).
For "fov 110" you could try "r_viewmodelSize 0.8" or 0.85 for example.

r_viewmodellastfired.desc: Display last fired weapon instead of currently held one on MVD / QTV playback.

r_viewmodeloffset.desc:
Moves the gun model to the right (positive value) or to the left (negative value).
Good for people who like to see right/left-handed looking weapons.
r_viewmodeloffset.remarks:
You can also change Y and Z coordinates, just provide parameters in "X Y Z" format.
See also r_shiftbeam variable.

r_viewpreselgun.desc: Will show a gun that was picked as the best by weapon pre-selection.

values.description: Display the weapon you really hold.
values.name: false

r_wallcolor.desc:
Changes color of walls when r_drawflat is set to 1.
Enter RGB value here, e.g. r_wallcolor "128 128 128" goes for gray walls.

r_watercolor.desc: Changes color of water when r_fastturb set to 1.

railcolor.remarks: Sent to server, requires mod support.

rate.desc: Sets the maximum amount of bytes per second that the server should send to the client.

rcon_address.desc: Address of the server to query with remote console commands.

rcon_password.desc: Password used for remote console communication.

re_trigger_match_0.desc: Whole matched pattern of the regular expression match.

re_trigger_match_1.desc: First matched subpattern of the regexp match.

ruleset.desc: Enforces a set of restrictions on the client features.

s_alsa_device.desc:
Sets which device ALSA will be trying to open (when s_driver is set to alsa).
Default is: "default", if that fails it will try "hw" and if that fails too, "plug:hw" will be tried.

s_alsa_latency.desc:
Specifies latency for ALSA.
If you got distortion in sound, upper the value a bit.
If you experience delays, try lowering this value.

s_alsa_noworkaround.desc: If you are having problems with ALSA you can try to set this var to 1 before you try legacy drivers.

values.description: Workaround disabled. Try this if you are having problems with new ALSA driver.

s_ambientfade.desc: How fast the volume of ambient sounds changes as you move around the map.

s_ambientlevel.desc: Volume level of ambient sounds (produced by liquid and sky brushes).

s_bits.desc: This defines how many sampling bits should be used, when using 16 bits the interpolation quality will be better.
s_bits.remarks:
Linux only.
Use s_restart after you change it.

s_chat_custom.desc: Controls usage of s_mm*, s_chat_*, s_otherchat_* and s_spec_* variables.

values.description: Chat sounds played for mm1 & mm2.
Chat sounds played for mm2 only.

s_desiredsamples.desc:
Indicates how large the audio buffer should be, in samples.
If 0, ezQuake will choose a sensible default, based on value of s_khz.
s_desiredsamples.remarks:
This is a suggestion only, the driver is free to choose a different value.
Smaller buffer sizes generally result in lower latency, but higher CPU usage.

s_device.desc: Allows you to choose from multiple sound devices.
s_device.remarks:
Linux only.
Use s_restart after you change it.

For OSS you should use "/dev/dsp", "/dev/dsp0", "/dev/dsp1", etc.
For ALSA use "default", "dmix", etc.

s_driver.desc: Specifices which sounddriver to use: ALSA/OSS or experimental Pulseaudio.

values.description: Will use experimental Pulseaudio drivers (note: have to be set in all loading configs before starting ezQuake to work!)
values.name: pulse

s_khz.desc:
The client includes "sound interpolation" which allows it to play sounds at higher frequencies, than the default 11025 Hz with perfect quality.
In addition to "s_khz" also "s_bits" (linux only) will have an influence on interpolation quality. This variable allows you to choose the frequency you want to interpolate the sounds to.
You will quickly discover, that the shaft sound is different at increased sampling rate. That's because shaft sounds were recorded at 22050 kHz, so probably that's how they should sound from the beginning. If you don't like it, you can always convert them to 11025.

s_linearresample.desc: Controls whether or not to resample sounds as they are loaded.

values.description: Upscale sounds as they are loaded.
Upscale & downscale sounds as they loaded, as appropriate.

s_linearresample_stream.desc: This variable is no longer used, and has no effect.

s_loadas8bit.desc: Reduce sound samples down to 8-bit at load time, trading quality for lower memory usage.
s_loadas8bit.remarks: This used to help with performance on systems with low memory.

s_mixahead.desc:
Only affects OSS and legacy ALSA:

This variable defines the delay time for sounds. How low you can set your sound mixahead depends on your FPS, when you set it too low, your sound will start crackling.
Generally, with 72 FPS you should be able to use a delay of 0.06 seconds.

s_mm1_file.desc: You can specify notification sound for messagemode1 (/messagemode or /say foo) messages.

s_mm1_volume.desc: You can specify volume of notification sound for messagemode1 (/messagemode or /say foo) messages.

s_mm2_file.desc: You can specify notification sound for messagemode2 (/messagemode2 or /say_team foo) messages.

s_mm2_volume.desc: You can specify volume of notification sound for messagemode2 (/messagemode2 or /say_team foo) messages.

s_noalsa.desc: Determinates sound output for linux clients: ALSA (0=default) or OSS.
s_noalsa.remarks: If you dont know what is ALSA and OSS - leave it at default value.

values.description: Makes Quake update its sound buffers more often to avoid choppy sound when your fps is really low (20 or worse)
values.name: false

values.description:
Don't use extra sound updates.
Gives a slight fps boost, but may lead to choppy sound on low-end machines.
values.name: true

values.description:
Disable the playback of sounds.
Note that it effectively just resets sound volume to zero, but the sound engine still runs.
If you want disable sound in order to get more fps, use the -nosound command line option instead.
values.name: true

s_oss_device.desc:
Specifies which device OSS will try to open.
Default is "/dev/dsp"

s_otherchat_file.desc: You can specify notification sound for other messages (than messagemode, messagemode2 and from spectators).

s_otherchat_volume.desc: You can specify volume of notification sound for other messages (than messagemode, messagemode2 and from spectators).

s_pulseaudio_latency.desc:
Specifies latency for Pulseaudio.
If you got distortion in sound, upper the value a bit.
If you experience delays, try lowering this value.

s_show.desc: Toggles displaying how many and/or which sound files are currently being played.

values.description: Print the number of sounds playing.
Print the volume in left/right speakers, name of sound file playing, and number of sounds playing.

s_silent_racing.desc: Toggles whether or not you can hear other players when racing.

s_spec_file.desc: You can specify notification sound for spectator messages.

s_spec_volume.desc: You can specify volume of notification sound for spectator messages.

s_stereo.remarks:
Linux only.
Use s_restart after you change it.

values.description: Will swap left and right sound channels.
values.name: true

s_uselegacydrivers.desc: If you are having problems with the new ALSA/OSS drivers you can enable this to be able to use legacy sound drivers, as in the ones used before v2.1.

values.description: Will use new sound drivers for ALSA/OSS.
Will use legacy drivers for ALSA/OSS (as used in versions before 2.1)

samelevel.desc:
When enabled, the same level will be played once the match is over.
Other mods use this value to store options.

values.description: Advance to next map after intermission.

sb_autohide.desc: This toggles in which cases the server browser should automatically hide itself when connecting to a server.

values.description: This will cause the server browser to always hide after connecting.

This will cause the server browser to hide after connecting only if the connected server is not a qizmo proxy.
Useful if you often connect to Qizmos only for rerouting features (with "useproxy 1")

sb_autoupdate.desc: Enabled auto-updates (pings & refreshes status) servers from actually marked server sources in Server Browser.
sb_autoupdate.remarks: Usefull with sb_starttab 1 and '+cfg_load myconfig +menu_slist' in command-line.

values.description: do not refresh server list automatically.
values.name: false

values.description: auto-refresh server list when first entering Server Browser menu.
values.name: true

sb_findroutes.desc: Enables automatic lookup of lowest ping path via proxies for connection to each server in the server browser.

values.description: Lookup will start after the "getting infos" phase.
values.name: true

sb_hidedead.desc: This toggles whether ezQuake should hide dead servers.

sb_hideempty.desc: This toggles whether ezQuake should hide empty servers.

sb_hidefull.desc: This toggles whether ezQuake should hide full servers.

sb_hidehighping.desc: Remove servers with high ping from the server list and also exclude them from querying servers for details.

sb_hidenotempty.desc: This toggles whether ezQuake should hide empty servers.

sb_inforetries.desc: This determines how often ezQuake should try to retrieve information from a server until it is considered to be not responding.

sb_infospersec.desc:
This determines how many serverinfos per second ezQuake should retrieve when scanning servers.
When setting this value too high you will flood your line, causing you to not receive information from servers or lagging your connection to the server you are currently connected to.

sb_infotimeout.desc: This determines how long ezQuake will wait for a reply when trying to retrieve information from a server until the attempt times out.

sb_info_filter.desc:
Allows custom filters to be written based on the serverinfo strings
Format is [+|-]infokey=value with +/- being include/exclude.
Can also specify +*/-* to include/exclude all, and +key/-key to include/exclude servers with any value for that key
Values are regular expressions, if the server doesn't have that key specified then the rule is skipped
sb_info_filter.remarks:
Default (if no rules match) is opposite of the last valid rule specified.
Rules should be separated by spaces
Examples

+ktxver               // pass any ktx server, hide others
+*gamedir=fortress    // pass Team Fortress servers, hide others
-*version=QTV*        // remove QTV servers
-map=dm4              // fourier woz ere

sb_listcache.desc: Cache the list of alive servers and load it on next startup of the client.

sb_liveupdate.desc:
This will determine how often ezQuake should refresh the serverinfo window, the specified value sets the delay in seconds.
Setting it to "0" will disable automatic refreshing.

sb_mastercache.desc:
This toggles whether ezQuake should cache the results of queries to master server (in directory qw/sb/cache).
If you restart ezQuake and don't update sources or if a master server is down, ezQuake will use the cache.

values.description: don't use cache for master servers.
values.name: false

values.description: use the cache for master servers when they are down or haven't been refreshed.
values.name: true

sb_masterretries.desc: This determines how often ezQuake should try to retrieve information from a master server until it is considered to be not responding.

sb_mastertimeout.desc: This determines how long ezQuake will wait for a reply when trying to retrieve information from a master server until the attempt times out.

sb_nosockraw.desc: Disable ICMP pinging in server browser and use UDP QW Ping packet to query servers for their ping (multithreaded).

sb_pinglimit.desc: Limit ping for servers to be visible when sb_hidehighping is enabled.

sb_pings.desc:
This determines how many pings ezQuake will send to a server when trying to determine your ping to it.
A higher value will cause scanning servers to take longer, but the result may be more exact.
A lower value obviously makes scanning faster, but pings may be inaccurate.

sb_pingspersec.desc:
This determines how many pings per second ezQuake should sent out when scanning servers.
If you set this value too high the result will be that the pings will not be accurate because you overloaded your line.
If you set it too low scanning servers will take very long especially when you have a large server list.

sb_pingtimeout.desc: This determines how long ezQuake will wait for a reply when trying to ping a server until the attempt times out.

sb_proxinfopersec.desc:
Number of proxies to contact per second.
Used when finding fastest path to a server.

sb_proxretries.desc: Number of times to attempt contact with a proxy before giving up.

sb_proxtimeout.desc: Timeout period (in ms) before a proxy connection times out.

sb_showaddress.desc: This toggles whether ezQuake should display the server IP column in the server list.

values.description: do not show the server IP column.
values.name: false

sb_showcounters.desc: This toggles whether ezQuake should display the number of servers or players in the status line.

values.description: do not show the server/player counter in the status line.
values.name: false

values.description: show the server/player counter in the status line.
values.name: true

sb_showfraglimit.desc: This toggles whether ezQuake should display the fraglimit column in the server list.

sys_inactivesound.desc: Enables sounds when the application is not focused.

sys_yieldcpu.desc:
Controls CPU sharing when client is waiting to draw a frame.
When disabled, client will run a loop, actively waiting for the time to draw a new frame.
When enabled, client will call system sleep function during the waiting, which will cause the thread to be deactivated for a while - leading to significantly lower CPU usage in most cases.

values.description: Do not sleep between frames, use CPU as much as possible.
values.name: false

values.description: Sleep between frames, make CPU available for other processes.
values.name: true
