tp_pointpriorities.desc: You can choose the way the client decides what object you want to point with $point macro.
tp_pointpriorities.remarks:
Priorities of object are given in tp_point command. You have to type all objects manually in tp_point command.

Example: tp_point quad ra mh health
In this example, quad has the highest priority and $point will always return quad if quad ra mh are all in your view.

Example: tp_point all
You never know what object will be pointed because all objects get the same priority.

values.description: Original, default behavior. The closest object will be chosen.
values.name: false

values.description: Object with highest priority will be chosen. First items in tp_point have highest priorities.
values.name: true

tp_pointtimeout.desc: Time (in seconds) before the last pointed item (%j) is cleared.

tp_poweruptextstyle.desc: Controls whether $tp_powerups (used in built-in binds) uses long or short-form powerup names.

tp_soundtrigger.desc:
SoundTrigger like proxys.
A SoundTrigger must be terminated by either a CR, LF or filter. The .wav extension is not required at the end.
Trigger is a character before the sound file.

Example:
filter #a
say_team I'm at %l ~location.wav"
say_team ~location.wav$\me: I'm at %l #a"
say_team ~location$\me: I'm at %l #a"
say_team I'm at %l ~location #a"

tp_tooktimeout.desc: Time (in seconds) before the last item taken (%X) is cleared.

tp_weapon_order.desc:
This allows you to define the order from best to worst weapon.
The default value is "78564321", which means that the Rocket Launcher is the best weapon (impulse 7), then Lightning Gun (impulse 8), Super Nailgun (impulse 5), Grenade Launcher (impulse 6), Nailgun (impulse 4), Super Shotgun (impulse 3), Shotgun (impulse 2), Axe (impulse 1).

userdir.desc:
userdir [dir [type]]
Addition of the given directory to the list searched files.

v_centermove.desc:
This variable sets the distance that the player must move before the screen automatically centers itself when "lookspring" is set to "1".
This variable is only useful to people who only play with the keyboard, have "lookspring" set to "1" and do not have "+klook" or "+mlook" enabled at that time.
When the player nmoves the distance specified in this variable the screen will pop back to the center position.

v_centerspeed.desc:
This variable sets how quickly your view returns to the center after looking up or down and moving after that and "lookspring" is set to "1".
This variable is only useful to people who only play with the keyboard, have "lookspring" set to "1" and do not have "+klook" or "+mlook" enabled at that time.
When the player moves the distance specified in this variable the screen will pop back to the center position.

v_contentblend.desc: Turning this variable on will temporarily change the hue of your screen when inside liquid (water/slime/lava) (requires gl_polyblend 1)
v_contentblend.remarks: Specify a percentage value, between 0 and 1.  0 turns the effect off.

v_damagecshift.desc: This variable (0..1) will temporarily add a red hue to your screen when you've taken damage. Needs gl_polyblend 1.

v_dlightcolor.desc:
Controls if the color of a light affects your view
Requires gl_polyblend & gl_flashblend set

v_dlightcshift.desc:
Controls when palette will change when inside a light bubble.
Also need to set gl_flashblend 1.

values.description: On, but excludes lights around players.

v_dlightcshiftpercent.desc: Strength of effect of v_dlightcshift, as a percentage

v_gunkick.desc: Kickback effect when the weapon is fired.

v_idlescale.desc:
This variable controls the amount that the screen should sway automatically.
When this variable is set to a value above "0" the screen will start swaying in all directions, similar as if the player was drunk of had a concussion.
If you want to have some real fun, set this variable to a value of "100" and run around some maps.
The larger the value for this variable the more the screen will sway from side to side.

v_ipitch_cycle.desc: This variable controls the speed at which the screen should sway up and down when "v_idlescale" is set to a value above "0".

v_ipitch_level.desc: This variable controls the distance that the screen should sway up and down when "v_idlescale" is set to a value above "0".

v_iroll_cycle.desc: This variable controls the speed at which the screen should roll clockwise and counter clockwise when "v_idlescale" is set to a value above "0".

v_iroll_level.desc: This variable controls the distance the screen should roll clockwise and counter clockwise when "v_idlescale" is set to a value above "0".

v_iyaw_cycle.desc: Sets how quickly you look left and right when v_idlescale is active.

v_iyaw_level.desc: Sets how far you look left and right when v_idlescale is active.

v_kickpitch.desc:
This variable controls the distance that the screen should move up or down when the player is shot.
Most players set this variable to "0" in order to remove the screen tilting effect when they are injured by a shot.
This allows them to keep a perfect aim while being fired upon.
v_kickpitch.remarks: v_kicktime must be >0 for this to take effect.

v_kickroll.desc:
This variable controls the distance that the screen should roll clockwise or counter clockwise when the player is shot.
Most players set this variable to "0" in order to remove the screen tilting effect when they are injured by a shot.
This allows them to keep a perfect aim while being fired upon.
v_kickroll.remarks: v_kicktime must be >0 for this to take effect.

v_kicktime.desc: This variable controls the amount of time v_kickpitch and v_kickroll take effect.

v_pentcshift.desc: This variable (0..1) will add a temporary red hue to your screen if you are carry the Pent powerup. Requires gl_polyblend 1.

v_quadcshift.desc: This variable (0..1) will add a temporary blue hue to your screen if you are carry the Quad powerup. Requires gl_polyblend 1.

v_ringcshift.desc: This variable (0..1) will add a temporary yellow hue to your screen if you are carry the Ring powerup. Requires gl_polyblend 1.

v_suitcshift.desc: This variable (0..1) will add a temporary green hue to your screen if you are carry the Suit powerup. Requires gl_polyblend 1.

v_viewheight.desc:
New variable v_viewheight can be used to get the effect of negative/zero values 
of cl_bobcycle etc in qw 2.33.
Negative values of v_viewheight = lower viewheight, 
positive = higher.
Can't go below -7 or above 4 because that's the range you can get with qw 2.33 by exploiting the bob cycle bug.

Using v_viewheight automatically turns off weapon model bobbing (cl_bob*).

vid_24bit_depth.remarks: Visual artifacts may be visible if using a 16-bit depth-buffer (e.g. entities disappearing at a distance).

values.description: Size of depth-buffer will be system default.
values.name: false

vid_conaspect.desc: Keep the screen proportions to given aspect ratio.
vid_conaspect.remarks: Always changes vid_conheight when you change vid_conwidth.

vid_config_x.desc: This variable sets the width of the vid_mode 2 window, the minimum possible value is "640".

vid_config_y.desc: This variable sets the width of the vid_mode 2 window, the minimum possible value is "400"

vid_conheight.remarks: Cannot be higher than the height of the current game resolution.

vid_conscale.desc: If vid_conwidth & vid_conheight are set to 0, vid_conheight will be scaled by the value of this variable.

vid_conwidth.remarks: Cannot be higher than the height of the current game resolution.

vid_customheight.desc: Screen resolution width for custom screen mode.

vid_customwidth.desc: Screen resolution height for custom screen mode.

vid_displayfrequency.desc: Sets horizontal frequency for your monitor (in hertz - Hz).

vid_displaynumber.desc: Display/screen to use when in fullscreen mode.
vid_displaynumber.remarks: Use vid_displaylist command to enumerate displays.

vid_flashonactivity.desc:
When there is activity in the server, ezQuake's taskbar window will flash.
Activity includes chat, high priority messages, disconnection from server.

vid_forcerestoregamma.desc: Force restore gamma after returning to minimized application.
vid_forcerestoregamma.remarks: Might be usefull if you have ATI card.

vid_framebuffer.desc: Enables rendering to custom Framebuffer Objects. ezQuake uses these FBOs for improved color, "render scale" control, and other post-processing effects.

values.description: Use separate FBOs for the 3D scene and HUD (allows scaling the two separately).

vid_framebuffer_blit.desc: Toggles blitting from the FBO to the front buffer instead of flipping buffers.
vid_framebuffer_blit.remarks: Only available with "vid_framebuffer 1" + "vid_software_palette 0" and a supported GPU.

vid_framebuffer_depthformat.desc: Configures the depth-buffer precision for the framebuffer.

values.description: Use the best precision available (up to 32-bit float).

vid_framebuffer_hdr.desc: Enables increased, 16-bit float HDR color precision for the framebuffer. This reduces color banding, and allows e.g. tone mapping in post-processing.

vid_framebuffer_hdr_tonemap.desc: Toggles tone mapping in HDR mode.

vid_framebuffer_height.desc: Sets a custom height for the FBO (200 pixels minimum).
vid_framebuffer_height.remarks: Setting vid_framebuffer_scale overrides custom FBO width/height.

vid_framebuffer_multisample.desc: The number of samples used around each pixel for anti-aliasing when using custom FBOs. Range 0-16.

vid_framebuffer_scale.desc: Scales the FBOs down/up to the screen resolution. Similar to "render scale" in other games if combined with vid_framebuffer 2.

values.description: Render to a larger FBO, then scale down.
Render to a smaller FBO, then scale up.
values.name: 1.x+

vid_framebuffer_smooth.desc: Toggles filtering when scaling the framebuffer up/down to the screen resolution (with either the vid_framebuffer_scale or width+height properties).
vid_framebuffer_smooth.remarks: Disable smoothing if you want to go for a chunky pixel look with FBO upscaling.

vid_framebuffer_sshotmode.desc: Controls screenshot resolution when using scaled framebuffers.

vid_framebuffer_width.desc: Sets a custom width for the FBO (320 pixels minimum).
vid_framebuffer_width.remarks: Setting vid_framebuffer_scale overrides custom FBO width/height.

vid_fullscreen.desc: Toggles between fullscreen and windowed mode.
vid_fullscreen.remarks: alt + enter toggles the setting and applies the change without a vid_restart.

vid_fullscreen_mode.desc: This variable sets the full screen video mode that the game will switch to when the "vid_fullscreen" command is executed.

values.description: Do not use sRGB rendering context.
Request sRGB rendering context, use if possible.
Request sRGB rendering context, reject non-sRGB contexts.

vid_gl_core_profile.desc: Controls the level of backwards compatibility of the Classic Renderer with legacy OpenGL features.

values.description: More backwards compatibility with older OpenGL.
values.name: false

values.description: Use the OpenGL Core profile, which drops older features. Disables immediate mode.
values.name: true

vid_grab_keyboard.desc:
If set, grabs keyboard hotkeys.
May need to be enabled/disabled depending on your window manager.

vid_height.desc: Determines width of screen resolution when in fullscreen mode.
vid_height.remarks: This value is ignored if vid_usedesktopres is set.

vid_hwgamma_fps.desc: Controls the frequency of hardware gamma updates per second. These updates have a performance cost, so it is preferred to not update every frame when playing at thousands of FPS.
vid_hwgamma_fps.remarks: This can really hurt performance on screen flashing effects, i.e when taking damage - the worst moment to suffer framerate dips!

values.description: Update hardware gamma at the specified frame rate.
Enables hwgamma control for fullscreen mode.
Enables hwgamma control for fullscreen and windowed mode.
Enables hwgamma even when window focus is lost but not minimized (Xorg only).

vid_minimize_on_focus_loss.desc: If set, ezQuake will minimise when running in fullscreen mode and it loses focus (e.g. alt-tab).

vid_mode.desc:
This variables sets the next video mode to be used.
Any change of this variable will cause the video mode to be changed immediately.

vid_nopageflip.desc:
This variable toggles the use of page-flipping during supported video modes.
By default the game will allow for page-flipping for video modes that support this feature.
For example if a given VESA mode can support page flipping, then it defaults to page-flipped operation.
A VESA mode can be forced to non-page-flipped operation by setting the "vid_nopageflip" variable to "1", then setting the mode (note that "vid_nopageflip" takes operation on the next, not the current video mode, and note that it then stays in effect permanently, even when the client is exited and restarted, unless it is manually set back to "0").
If there is not enough memory for two pages in a VESA mode, or if the adapter doesn't support page flipping, then the mode will automatically be nnon-page-flipped.

Page-flipping works by drawing multiple virtual game screens at the same time in the video memory and then switching among them to display the current gamescreen. Page-flipped modes thus use less system memory than non-page-flipped modes, but require more video memory.
When using page-flipping, visual quality may be higher, but performance of the game can change to better or worse, depending on the graphics adapter and other hardware (see the discussion of the Pentium Pro below, for a discussion of why page flipping can be faster but is sometimes much slower on that processor). However in most cases the performance (and thus frame rate) will be increased, but for people with hardware that has problems with page-flipping "vid_nopageflip 1" may help.
The Pentium Pro is an example for such a hardware: it is an okay client platform (sniff!), but it has one weak spot, it is by default very slow on writes to video memory.
This means that in default hardware configurations, you are usually much better off setting "vid_nopageflip" to "1" if you use VESA modes, so drawing is done to system memory instead of to video memory.
Remember that you must set the mode after setting "vid_nopageflip" to "1" in order to get "vid_nopageflip" to take effect. "vid_nopageflip 1" can sometimes be faster on a Pentium too, but not by nearly as much in general, and it's often slower.

vid_renderer.desc: Selects which rendering mode to use.
vid_renderer.remarks: (variable only available if multiple renderers available)

vid_resetonswitch.remarks:
This is a workaround for the bug in some NVidia drivers, when you alt-tab out of ezQuake and the screen gets garbaged.
When enabled, the client will reset your Windows video mode every time you press alt-tab. Note that some NVidia drivers lock up your system completely when you alt-tab: vid_resetonswitch will not help in this case (try starting ezQuake with -dibonly).

vid_showextensions.desc: If set, GL_EXTENSIONS string will be displayed when printing graphics info.

vid_software_palette.desc: Controls whether to adjust gamma at the display level, or as a color correction rendering effect.

vid_stretch_by_2.remarks: This variable toggles whether in "vid_mode 2" the picture should be rendered at half-resolution in each direction and stretched up to the specified size.

vid_usedesktopres.desc: If set, vid_width/vid_height are ignored, and desktop resolution is used instead.

vid_verbose.desc: If set, display graphics info on every vid_restart.

vid_vsync.desc: Syncs your FPS with your monitor's vertical refresh rate. This will override cl_maxfps.

vid_vsync_lag_fix.desc: Enables experimental fix for a delay vertical synchronization mode.
vid_vsync_lag_fix.remarks: When vid_vsync is set to 1, an artificial delay in the input can appear, enabling this should eliminate the delay.

vid_vsync_lag_tweak.desc: Custom value for experimental vertical synchronization delay reduction.
vid_vsync_lag_tweak.remarks:
Too low values (0.2 or lower) may significantly decrease FPS and make it not synced with display frequency.
Too high values (10 and above) may turn off the effect of video lag fix completely.
Use the lowest value that keeps stable FPS for you.

vid_wideaspect.desc:
Recalculates screen proportions so that they suit wide-screen displays.
If you toggle this variable from 0 to 1, it will recalculate your field of view (fov) and screen proportions (conwidth/conheight ratio) so that the resulting image looks similar on a 16:10 screen as it did on 4:3 screen.
vid_wideaspect.remarks: The effect of the variable is only changing values of "fov" and "vid_conheight" variables when you toggle the value of this variable. The algorithm used to get resulting values is described in the QuakeWorld wiki.

values.description: Keep the settings suitable for 4:3 screen.
values.name: false

vid_width.desc: Determines width of screen resolution when in fullscreen mode.
vid_width.remarks: This value is ignored if vid_usedesktopres is set.

vid_win_borderless.desc: Enables borderless windowed mode (no window title, frame...). Useful for multi-monitor setups, where it can provide a fullscreen window that does not pause when out of focus.

vid_win_displaynumber.desc: Display/screen to use when in windowed mode.
vid_win_displaynumber.remarks: Use vid_displaylist command to enumerate displays.

vid_win_height.desc: Height of display when in windowed mode.

vid_win_save_pos.desc: If set, window position variables will be set as window moved around screen.

vid_win_save_size.desc: If set, window size variables will be set as window resized.

vid_win_width.desc: Width of display when in windowed mode.

vid_window_x.desc: This variable sets the x-axis location of the top left corner of the game window on the desktop.

vid_window_y.desc: This variable sets the y-axis location of the top left corner of the game window on the desktop.

vid_windowed_mode.desc: This variable sets the windowed video mode that the game will switch to when the "vid_windowed" command is executed.

vid_xpos.desc: Horizontal position of the client window.

vid_ypos.desc: Vertical position of the client window.

viewsize.desc: This variable determines how large the viewable screen size is.
viewsize.remarks:
Value range is 30-120.
Values 100 & 110 are affected by cl_sbar.

values.description: Large screen size, without the weapons status bar.
Maximum screen size, without any status bars.

volume.remarks: This can go above 1, but sound will get more and more distorted.

w_switch.desc:
This variable allows you to define the highest weapon that the client should switch to when picking it up.
The possible arguments of "w_switch" refer to the impulse that is used to switch to a certain weapon:

watervis.desc: This server-side cvar is mirrored to serverinfo as a hint to clients on whether the server is using the so-called watervised maps.
watervis.remarks:
It's a bad idea to use watervis 1 if the maps the server is using are not watervised.
Liquids will appear 'transparent' but you won't be able to see any items/players/etc through it.
It is a bad idea anyway because Quake maps were not designed for transparent water (or other liquids); enabling it changes gameplay, decreases fps and produces more network traffic and puts non-GL players at a disadvantage because the software renderer doesn't support transparent water (yet).
Not saved to config with cfg_save command.

values.description: GLQuake users can see through liquids if they set gl_turbalpha to a value < 1.
values.name: true

zombietime.desc: The number of minutes that the server will keep the character of a player on the map who seems to have disconnected.
